title: Did Albert Einstein know how to play the violin? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, Albert Einstein, and many of his direct descendants, played the violin. Einstein was passionate about the violin, and though Einstein often had a distant and strained relationship with his family, he shared a love music, and left his violin as a legacy. Einstein's remarkable talent was for physics, but he played the violin throughout his life, and he was a good musician with an intuitive understanding of the music. Playing the violin brought him happiness, and he bequeathed his last violin (said to be nicknamed Lina), to his grandson, Bernhard Caesar Einstein.  Bernhard Caesar, also became a physicist and shared Albert's ability to play the violin. Bernhard Caeser's second son, Paul Michael Einstein, also inherited the love of playing and Bern­hard Caesar gave him Albert's violin.  Today Paul Michael lives in the South of France, where he is a professional composer and violinist. In 2004, Paul Michael performed Mozart’s Sonata in E Minor, Albert’s favorite piece, at the German Physical Society’s celebration of Albert Einstein’s 125th birthday.  All of Einstein's descendants didn't inherit Einstein's IQ, but many of them did inherit his love of music and ability to play the violin. And, studies have indicated that Musicians Are Probably Smarter Than The Rest Of Us.

Yes.  Einstein could play both the piano and the violin. Playing the violin was very important to Albert Einstein.  He started lessons at the age of six. He is reported to have owned more than ten violins. In a letter to Philipp Frank, in 1940, Einstein wrote:  "I took violin lessons from age 6 to 14, but had no luck with my teachers, for whom music did not transcend mechanical practicing.  I really began to learn only when I was about 13 years old, mainly after I had fallen in love with Mozart's sonatas." In an interview by G.S. Viereck titled "What Life Means to Einstein", that appeared in the Saturday Evening Post on 26 October, 1929, Einstein said:  "If I were not a physicist, I would probably be a musician.  I often think in music.  I live my daydreams in music.  I see my life in terms of music." and "I cannot tell if I would have done any creative work of importance in music, but I do know that I get most joy in life out of my violin." Source:

response.answer_text: He frequently played classical music as a brainstorming technique. “As a little girl,” Einstein's second wife Elsa once remarked, “I fell in love with Albert because he played Mozart so beautifully on the violin. He also plays the piano. Music helps him when he is thinking about his theories.  Source- Six Interesting Musical Facts About Albert Einstein

Considering that nobody knows how to play the violin, then, Einstein knew as well as any. What determines "know how" to it? Little kids toying around with it having a great time, are far superior in experience, context and concept than some university-enrolled dogmatic person doing finger or sheet music routines day after day, year after year with rarely a smile or sense of wonder or generosity in their hearts.

The most popular quotes re Einstein&music are taken from the interview George Sylvester Viereck published first in October 1929 in English. However, there are good reasons - based on who GSViereck was and how he used to edit his interviews, on the language of the interview i.e. the communication/understanding etc. - to challenge the authenticity of these quotes. - Einstein himself has written a lot about music in the broadest sense, and reliable contemporaries and related persons have reported on Einstein as a musician (but keep away from Peter Bucky’s composition), so Viereck can just be ignored (“daydreams”..”would probably be a musician”..”life in terms of music”…).- That Mozart’s Sonata in E Minor was Albert’s favorite piece is nonsense, there are a few pieces he mentions here and there, very few btw., usually he mentions only the composer’s name, and in all his letters and other texts we don’t find “one favorite piece” but a small number of pieces he liked or he recommended.- The most reliable report on Einstein&music was delivered by a professional, Boris Schwarz, who started to play more or less regularly with Einstein as a young boy in the 1920s and saw Einstein for musical sessions until the end of Einstein’s life.
Of course! I think it powered his brain as well as his ability to think differently from others. the following pictures will explain this:     We musicians have our own way of thinking, like:

It's worth noting that the following was said in the 20's:  "...while playing violin in a quartet, Einstein repeatedly made wrong entrances during the rehearsal. The exasperated pianist, Artur Schnabel, eventually turned to him and said: 'For heaven's sake, Albert, can't you count?'"

Short answer - the same reason most children get into music - parents, in Albert Einstein’s case, his mom - “Pauline Koch Einstein was an accomplished pianist in her own right, and taught Einstein to play the piano and violin when he was very young. Initially he showed more aptitude for the piano, but as he became a teenager he developed more interest in the violin.” More here.
